newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan coalition talks drag on, only partial deal.
newsitem.headline: Japan coalition talks drag on, only partial deal.

text.p: Potential coalition partners in Japan's hung parliament failed to strike a deal to form a new government on Monday, remaining far apart on security issues and political reform, party officials said.

Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) began negotiations last Saturday with its old allies, the Social Democrats and the Sakigake party, after failing to win a parliamentary majority in general elections on October 20.
The talks were to continue on Tuesday. The government has said it would reconvene parliament on November 7 to elect a new prime minister.

"We did agree to set up a watchdog group within parliament to oversee the conduct of bureaucrats," said Taku Yamazaki, the LDP policy head, but he added that there was still no convergence of view on some other key issues.
"We are on a parallel track with our partners on security issues and political donations," he told a news conference.
Streamlining the bloated and overly powerful bureaucracy was the biggest issue in the general elections, after a series of scandals involving the finance and health ministries.
Hashimoto could be forced to lead an unstable minority government should he fail to cement a renewed alliance.
The LDP holds 239 seats, a dozen short of a majority in parliament's powerful Lower House.
It needs the Social Democrats' 15 Lower House seats and 32 Upper House seats to command majorities in both houses. Sakigake has two Lower House and four Upper House seats.

But fearful of becoming an irrelevant force in an LDP-dominated coalition, the Social Democrats have demanded that the LDP agree to a blanket ban on political donations from corporations, and agree to scale down a set of new military guidelines under the U.S.-Japan Security Treaty.
The two issues are anathema to the LDP, which has long aimed to strengthen military ties with the United States and has survived on donations from big businesses.
The representative from the third party in the talks, Sakigake deputy chief Hiroyuki Sonoda, said the three parties also agreed to review the new electoral system.
"We have agreed to conduct a thorough review of the electoral system," Sonoda said after Monday's talks.
"This includes the problem of double candidates. We also agreed to reduce the overall number of (Lower House) seats."

Under the system introduced in the October 20 general elections, a candidate running in one of 300 single-seat constituencies could also be listed on the party proportional representation list in 11 regional blocs.

In some cases, candidates finishing a dismal fourth in the first-past-the-post constituency won seats anyway as a result of the party gaining enough votes through proportional representation, even though the second or third finisher failed to win a seat.
That twist in the system came under severe criticism from voters and political analysts.
